required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Clamping the Indwelling Urethral Catheter Before Removal From Patients After Type III Radical Hysterectomy

lead_sponsor.agency: First Affiliated Hospital of Chongqing Medical University

clinical_study.source: First Affiliated Hospital of Chongqing Medical University

brief_summary.textblock: The effect of clamping the indwelling urethral catheter before removal is an unsettled issue in clinical practice. No studies have done before in the patients with gynecologic cancers who received radical hysterectomy. We hypothesized that clamping the catheter would decrease the rate of recatheterization. In addition, the feeling of urination during clamping is correlated with lower rate of recatheterization after removal.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Supportive Care

arm_group.description: to clamp or release the catheter for 2 days before removal

intervention.intervention_name: to clamp or release the catheter for 2 days before removal

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients receiving Piver III radical hysterectomy
- catheterization over 7 days
Exclusion Criteria:
- catheterization shorter than 7 days

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: First Affiliated Hospital of Chongqing Medical University
